Assess,\n Classify & \nTreat

• Care for the child who returns for follow up visit using all the boxes that match the child\'s previous classifications.\n • If the child has any new problem, assess, classify fully and treat as on the assess classify and treat on the mainmenu.

resources.string: Item Icon
Open Drawer

Key Elements of IMCI
 1. Assessment 
 	Assess for general danger signs 
 	Assess for common illnesses 

2. Classification

3. Identify Treatment 
 
 4. Treat
 	Treat means giving prescribed treatment in the facility, prescribing other drugs or other treatments to be administered at home 
 
 5. Counsel
 	 Educate the mother on signs indicating child requires urgent follow up, feeding and care for development 
 
 6. Follow up
Child 0 to 2 months
Child 2 to 60months(5years)
Proceed

1. Determine whether it is the initial visit or just a follow up of an illness

 2. If it is a follow up head to Treatment Chart in the Treat Child Tab

 3. If it is an initial visit assess the child as follow

ASSESSMENT

 Ask the mother what the child's problems are 
 		 1. Determine whether it is the initial visit or just a follow up of an illness if it is a follow up use the follow up button on the mainmenu.
 if it is an initial visit assess the child as follow: 
 ---

Ask 

	 • Is the child able to breastfeed or drink?

	 • Does the child vomit everything? 

	 • Has the child had convulsions? 
 

Look:

	 • See if child is lethargic or unconscious 

	 • Is the child convulsing now ? 
 If yes treat immediately. 
 If not proceed to ask for main symptoms.

Determine if this is an initial or follow-up visit for this problem 

	 - If follow-up, use the follow-up on the mainmenu. 

	 - If it is an initial visit, assess the young infant as follows:

Does the child have Cough or difficult breathing ?
 IF YES ASK 
 For how long?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Count the breaths in one minute.
 • Look for chest indrawing.
 • Look and listen for stridor.
 • Look and listen for wheeze.

Child must be calm
 IF CHILD IS: 
 • 2 months up to 12 months fast breathing is 50 breaths per minute or more.
 • 12 months up to 5 years fast breathing is 40 breaths per minute or more.
 PLEASE CLASSIFY IF IT'S A COUGH OR DIFFICULT BREATHING

Does the child have diarrhoea?
 
 FOR HOW LONG?
 Is there blood in the stool?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Look at the child’s general condition.
 • Is the child: Lethargic or unconscious?
 Is the child restless and irritable?
 • Look for sunken eyes.
 • Offer the child fluid. Is the child not able to drink or drinking poorly?
 • Pinch the skin of the abdomen. Does it go back: 
Very slowly(SEVERE DEHYDRATION) (longer than 2 sec.), 
Slowly(SOME DEHYDRATION), 
Immediately(NO DEHYDRATION)?


 PLEASE CLASSIFY FOR: 1.DEHYDRATION 
2.DIARRHOEA FOR 14 DAYS OR MORE(PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA) 
3.IF BLOOD IN THE STOOL(DYSENTRY)

Does the child have fever?
 IF YES ASK 
 Has the child travelled to a high risk Malaria area in the last one month ?
 THEN ASK:
 For how long?
 If more than 7 days , has fever been present every day?
 Has the child had signs of measles within the last 3 months?


LOOK AND FEEL
 • Look and feel for stiff neck.
 • Look for runny nose.
 • Look for signs of measles …generalized rash and one of these runny nose, cough or red eyes.
 
 DO A MALARIA TEST
 IF (Test = positive){
 P.falciparum PRESENT
 P.vivax PRESENT}
 ELSE {
 P.falciparum ABSENT
 P.vivax ABSENT
 }

NOTE: if you can’t test, don’t withhold treatment

Check for complications of Measles
 • Look for mouth ulcers, are they deep or extensive?
 • Look for pus draining from the eye.
 • Look for clouding of their cornea.
 CLASSIFICATIONS 
 1.High malaria risk
 2.Low malaria risk
 3.Measles

Does the child have an ear problem
 IF YES ASK 
 Is there ear pain?
 Is there ear discharge? If yes, how long?
 LOOK, AND FEEL 
 • Look for pus draining from the ear.
 • Feel for tender swelling behind the ear?

Check for Malnutrition and anaemia

ASK: Is there history of TB contact?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Take the child’s weight and plot it against mother / child health booklet to determine the z-score.
 • Take the child’s length/height for age and plot on mother /child health booklet to determine the z_score.
 • Determine the growth patter: is the growth faltering?(Weight curve is flattening or dropping for at least 2 consecutive months? )
 • Look for oedema of both feet
 • Look for visible severe wasting.
 For children aged 6 months up to 59 months, determine MUAC:
 • less than 11.5cm
 • 11.5-12.5cm
 • 12.5-13.5cm
 Determine Z score for the same :
 • les than-3
 • -3 to less than -2
 • -2 to less than -1
 • -1 to +2

 CHECK FOR ANAEMIA
 Look for palmar pallor, is it:
 • Severe palmar pallor?
 • Some palmar pallor?
 • No palmar pallor?

CHECK FOR HIV EXPOSURE AND INFECTION
 ASK
 • Ask for mother’s HIV status to establish child’s HIV exposure…reactive, non reactive, unknown.
 • Ask if child has had any TB contact.

LOOK, FEEL AND DIAGNOSE:
 For child less than 18 months
 • If mother’s HIV status is unknown, conduct an antibody test (rapid test)on either r mother or child.
 • If mother’s or child’s antibody test is POSITIVE the child is HIV exposed. Take DBS for DNA PCR testing at six weeks or earliest contact thereafter
 For child >18 months If Mother is POSITIVE conduct rapid test on child as the child is exposed.

ASK AND CHECK RECORD FOR SPECIAL TREATMENT NEEDS 

 • Has the mother had within 2 weeks of delivery:
 		-fever?
 		-infectiontreated with antibiotic? 
 • Membranes raptured for over 18 hours before delivery?
 • Foul smelling liquor.
 • Mother tested VDRL positive?
 • Mother tested HIV positive?
 		-Is or has been on ARVs?
 		-Has received infant feeding counselling?
 • Is the mother receiving TB treatment which began less than 2 months ago?

IF YES ASK 
 		For how long?
 		Is there blood in the stool? 

 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 
 • Look at the child’s general condition.
 • Is the child: Lethargic or unconscious? Is the child restless and irritable?
 • Look for sunken eyes.
 • Offer the child fluid. Is the child not able to drink or drinking poorly?
 • Pinch the skin of the abdomen. Does it go back: Very slowly (longer than 2 sec.), Slowly, Immediately?

ASK
 • Ask for mother's HIV status to establish child's HIV exposure.Is it:
 		-Reactive.
 		-Non reactive.
 		-Unknown.
 • Ask if child has had any TB contact.

 LOOK,FEEL AND DIAGNOSE:
 Child less than 18 months
 • If Mother's HIV status is unknown,conduct an antibady test(rapid test) on mother or child to determine HIV exposure.
 •If mother's or child's antibody test is POSITIVE the child is HIV exposed. Take DBS for DNA PCR test at six weeks or earliest contact thereafter.

ASK:
 • Is the infant breastfed?
 If yes,how many times during the day__During the night__ How many times in 24 hours?__
 If no, ask why?__
 • Does the infant usually receive any other foods or drinks?
 • How do you prepare the feeds?
 • What do you use to feed the infant?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL: 

Determine weight for age.
 • Look for ulcers or white patches in the mouth(thrush).
 • Determine mother's HIV status:
 		-Reactive.
 		-Non reactive.
 		-Unknown.
 • Determine HIV exposed Infant's HIV status:
 	-Positive.
 	-Negative.
 	-Unknown. 

 If the infant has no indications for urgent referral to hospital from previous assessment:
 • Discuss infant feeding options with the mother.
 • FOR A MOTHER WHO HAS DECIDED TO BREASTFEED:
 ASSESS BREASTFEEDING:
 • Has the infant breastfed in the previous hour?
 • If the infant has not fed in the previous hour,ask the mother to put her infant to the breast. Observe the breastfeed for 4 minutes.
 • (If the infant was fed during the last hour, ask the mother if she can wait and tell you when the infant is willing to feed again.)

 TO CHECK CORRECT POSITIONING, LOOK FOR:
 -Infant's head and body straight.
 -Infant facing the mother's breast with nose opposite the nipple.
 -Infant's body close to the mother's body.
 -Mother supporting infant's whole body.
 Is the child well positioned?
 • Well positioned
 • Not well positioned.
 
 TO CHECK ATTACHMENT, LOO FOR:
 	-Chin touching breast.
 	-Mouth wide open.
 	-Lower lipturn outward.
 	-More areola visible above than below the mouth.
 (All of these signs should be present if the attachment is good.)
 • Is the infant able to attach?
 	-not well attached.
 	-good attachment.
 • Is the infant sucking effectively(that is, slow deep sucks,sometimes pausing)?
 	-not sucking effectively.
 	-sucking effectively.
 • Clear a blocked nose if it interferes with breastfeeding.
 • Look for ulcers or white patches in the mouth(Thrush).

IF YES ASK :
 For how long?
 Is there blood in the stool?

 LOOK,LISTEN,FEEL:
 Look at the young infant’s general condition.

 Is the infant:
 • Lethargic or unconscious?
 • Restless and irritable?
 		-Look for sunken eyes.
 		-Pinch the skin of the abdomen.
 		-Does it go back:
 • Very slowly(longer than 2 seconds)?
 • Slowly?
 • Immediately?

• Lethargic or unconscious.
 • Sunken eyes.
 • Skin pinch goes back very slowly

• Restless,irritable
 • Sunken Eyes
 • Drink eagerly,thirsty
 • Skin pinch goes back slowly
Not enough signs to classify as some or severe dehydration
SEVERE DEHYDRATION
SOME DEHYDRATION
NO DEHYDRATION

ASK
 		Has the infant had convulsions?
 		Is the infant not able to feed or breast feed?
 LOOK,LISTEN,FEEL:

 • Look for breathing: Is the baby gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated.
 • Count the breaths in one minute. Repeat the count if elevated.
 • Look for severe chest indrawing .
 • Look and listen for grunting or wheezing.
 • Look for nasal flaring.
 • Look for central cyanosis.
 • Look and feel for bulging fontanel.
 • Look for pus draining from the ear.
 • Look at the umbilicus. Is it red or draining pus?
 • Measure temperature or feel for low or high body temperature.
 • Look for skin pustules.
 • See if the young infant is drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious.
 • Look at the young infant’s movements. Does the infant not move even when stimulated?
 • Listen for very high pitched cry.
 • Look for stiff neck.
VERY SEVERE DISEASE
LOCAL BACTERIAL INFECTION
VERY SEVERE DISEASE OR LOCAL BACTERIAL INFECTION UNLIKELY
LOW BODY TEMPERATURE

ASK
 • Does the young infant have yellow discoloration of palms and soles? Check if this is so.
 • If yes, for how long?
 
 LOOK 
 • Look at the young infants palms and soles. 
 	-Are they yellow? 

 Classify Jaundice.

IF YES, ASK:

 For how long?

 LOOK AND FEEL:
 • Crossed eyes
 • Excessive tearing.
 • Fear of light.
 • Clouding of the cornea.
 • Squeezing of the eyes.
 • Red eyes.
 • Whiteness in the pupil.
 • Eyes discharge, if yes for how long?
 • Eyes draining pus.
 • Swollen eyes.

ASK 
 • Ask for mother\’s HIV status to establish child’s HIV exposure.
 Is it:
 		-Reactive
 		-Non reactive
 		-Unknown
 • Ask if child has had any TB contact.

 LOOK, FEEL AND DIAGNOSE:

 Child less 18months
 • If Mother’s HIV status is unknown, conduct an antibody test (rapid test) on mother or child to determine Hiv exposure.
 • If mother is or child’s antibody test is POSITIVE the child is HIV exposed.
 Take DBS for DNA PCR testing at six weeks or earliest contact thereafter.
 PRESUMPTIVE SYMPTOMATIC DIAGNOSIS OF HIV INFECTION IN CHILDREN 18MONTHS
 LOOK and FEEL
 • Pneumonia***
 • Oral Candidiasis / thrush
 • Severe sepsis
 • Other AIDS defining conditions**

CHECK FOR EYE INFECTIONS
 IF YES, ASK: 
 For how long?
 LOOK AND FEEL:
 • Crossed eyes
 • Excessive tearing
 • Fear of light
 • Clouding of the cornea
 • Squeezing of the eyes
 • Red eyes
 • Whiteness in the pupil
 • Eyes discharge, if yes for how long?
 • Eyes draining pus
 • Swollen eyes

SQUINT 

 CONGENITAL CANCER OF THE EYE 


CONGENITAL GLAUCOMA


 SEVERE EYE INFECTION
EYE INFECTION

Does the child have Cough or difficult breathing ?
 IF YES ASK 

 For how long?

 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL

 • Count the breaths in one minute.
 • Look for chest indrawing.
 • Look and listen for stridor.
 • Look and listen for wheeze.

Child must be calm

 IF CHILD IS: 
 • 2 months up to 12 months fast breathing is 50 breaths per minute or more.
 • 12 months up to 5 years fast breathing is 40 breaths per minute or more.

Does the child have fever? 
 IF YES ASK 

 Has the child travelled to a high risk Malaria area in the last one month ?
 THEN ASK:
 For how long?
 If more than 7 days , has fever been present every day?
 Has the child had signs of measles within the last 3 months?

LOOK AND FEEL 
 • Look and feel for stiff neck.
 • Look for runny nose.
 • Look for signs of measles …generalized rash and one of these runny nose, cough or red eyes.

DO A MALARIA TEST
 IF (Test = positive){
 P.falciparum PRESENT and P.vivax PRESENT}

 or ELSE {
 P.falciparum ABSENT and P.vivax ABSENT
 }



NOTE: if you can’t test, don’t withhold treatment


Check for complications of Measles
 • Look for mouth ulcers, are they deep or extensive?
 • Look for pus draining from the eye.
 • Look for clouding of their cornea.

• Any general danger sign
 • Chest indrawing
 • Stridor in calm child
 • Fast breathing
 • No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.
• Fast Breathing\n
• No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.\n

• Lethargic or unconscious
 • Sunken eyes
 • Not able to drink or drink poorly
 • Skin pinch goes back very slowly

• Lethargic or unconscious\n
• Sunken eyes\n • Skin pinch goes back very slowly.
• Diarrhoea lasting 7 days or more.\n
• Not low weight for age and no other signs of inadequate feeding.
• Not enough signs to classify as some or severe dehydration.\n

• Restless, irritable
 • Sunken eyes
 • Drinks eagerly,thirsty
 • Skin pinch goes back slowly
• Restless, irritable\n • Sunken eyes\n • Skin pinch goes back slowly
• Dehydration present.
• No Dehydration.
• Blood in the stool.
• Tender swelling behind the ear\n
• Pus is seen draining from the ear\n • Discharge is reported for less than 14 days,or ear pain\n
• Pus is seen draining from the ear or discharge is reported for 14 days or more.
• No ear pain and No pus seen or reported draining from ear.
• Any general danger sign.\n • Stiff neck.
• Malaria test POSITIVE.

• Malaria test NEGATIVE.
 • Runny nose PRESENT.
 • Measles PRESENT.
 • Other causes of fever PRESENT.
• No general danger sign.\n • No stiff neck.\n • Malaria test negative.
• Generalized rash of measles and One of cough,runny nose
• Clouding of cornea.\n • Deep or extensive mouth ulcers.
• Pus draining from the eye.\n • Mouth ulcers.
• No pus draining from the eyes or mouth ulcers.

• With visible wasting.
 • Oedema of both feet. 
 • less than-3 Z Score ( weight for or weight for height/length)
 FOR CHILDREN 6MONTHS UPTO MUAC less than 11.5cm
• Static weight or losing.\n • 3 to less than -2 Z- Score\n IF AGE 6 MONTHS UPTO 59 MONTHS MUAC 11.5 TO 12.5cm
• Static weight or losing weight\n • 2 to less than -1 Z-Score\n "IF AGE 6MONTHS UPTO 59 MONTHS MUAC 12.5 TO 13.5cm"
• weight -1 to +2.
• Severe palmar pallor.
• Some palmar pallor.
• No palmar pallor.
• Child less 18 months and DNA PCR test POSITIVE.\n • Child above 18 months and Antibody test POSITIVE.
• Child less 18 months and DNA PCR test POSITIVE.

• Not well attached to breast or. 
 • Not sucking effectively.
 • Breastfeeds less than 8 times in 24 hours or.
 • Receives other foods or drinks or.
 • Low weight for age or 
 • Thrush (white patches in mouth)or
 • Mouth ulcers
• Not low weight for age and no other signs of inadequate feeding. \n
• Weight less than 2 kg.
• Weight between 2 kg and 2.5kg.
• Weight 2.5kg or more.

• If mother's HIV status is POSITIVE and no result for child.
 or 
 • If child antibody test shows POSITIVE.
 or 
 • If DNA PCR test is negative.

•No test results for child or mother. 
 • 2 or more of the following conditions: 
 		 -Severe Pneumonia
 		 -Candidiasis/thrush
 		 -Severe Sepsis
 or 
 • An AIDS defining condition.
•If child is 18 less months with UNKNOWN mother\'s HIV tests Negative \n •If child is above 18 months and tests antibody NEGATIVE.

• Gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated 
 • Respiratoy rate less than 20 breaths per minute
 • Convulsions or convulsing now
 • Not able to feed or breastfeed 
 • Fast breathing (60 breaths per minute or more)
 • Severe chest indrawing
 • Nasal flaring
 • Central cyanosis
 • Bulging fontanelle
 • Pus draining from the ear 
 • Fever above 37.5 degrees celcius
 • Very low body temperature
 • Drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious
 • No movements even when stimulated
 • Very high pitched cry 
 • Stiff neck.
• Red umbilicus or draining pus or\n • Skin pustules.
• None ot the signs or very severe disease
• Temperature 35.5-36.4.

• Baby less 1 day old and membranes ruptured for more than 18hrs before delivery or
 • Foul smelling liqour or
 • Mother being treated for antibiotics for infection or
 • Mother has fever:temperature above 38 degrees.
• Mother tested VDRL positive.

• Mother confirmed HIV positive and not on ARV's.
 • Mother has not been counseled on infant feeding.
 • Mother chose breastfeeding.
 • Mother chose replacement breastfeeding.
• Mother started TB treatment less than 2 months before delivery.

string-array.name: array_cough
string-array.item: No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.

string-array.name: array_diarrhoea
string-array.item: Not able to drink or drink poorly
Skin pinch goes back very slowly
Not enough signs to classify as some or severe dehydration

string-array.name: array_fever
string-array.item: Generalized rash of measles and One of cough,runny nose
No pus draining from the eyes or mouth ulcers

string-array.name: array_ear
string-array.item: Pus is seen draining from the ear
Discharge is reported for less than 14 days,or ear pain
Discharge is reported for less 14 days
No ear pain and No pus seen or reported draining from ear

string-array.name: array_malnutrition
string-array.item: For children 6 months upto 59 months : MUAC less 11.5cm
If age 6 months upto 59 months MUAC 11.5 to 12.5 cm
less than 2 to less than 1 Z score
If age 6 months upto 59 months MUAC 12.5 to 13.5cm

string-array.name: array_hiv
string-array.item: Child less 18 months and DNA PCR test POSITIVE
Child above 18 months and Antibody test POSITIVE
If mother\'s HIV status is POSITIVE and no test for child
If child is antibody test POSITIVE
No test results for child or mother
If child is 18 less months with UNKNOWN mother\'s HIV tests Negative
If child is above 18 months and tests antibody NEGATIVE
Pus is seen draining from the ear is reported for ...
2 or more of the following conditions

string-array.name: young_array_very_severe_disease
string-array.item: Gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated
Respiratoy rate less than 20 breaths per minute
Not able to feed or breastfeed
Fast breathing (60 breaths per minute or more)
Red umbilicus or draining pus or skin pustules
None ot the signs or very severe disease

resources.string: • Yellow palms and soles at any age. \n • Any jaundice if age less than 24 hours OR more than 14 days of age.\n
• No yellow palms and soles. \n • Jaundice appearing between 24 hours and 14 days of age.\n
• No signs to classify as severe jaundice.
• Crossed eyes.
• White spot on pupil.\n • Crossed eyes.
• Clouding of the cornea and signs of Measles,\n • Fear of light and excessive tearing.
• Eyes swollen and draining pus.
• Eyes are red or have a discharge.
• No signs to classify for congenital or eye infection.

string-array.name: young_array_jaundice
string-array.item: Yellow palms and soles at any age
Any jaundice if age less than 24 houes OR more than 14 days of age
Jaundice appearing between 24 hours and 14 days of age
No signs to classify as severe jaundice

string-array.name: young_array_eyeinfection
string-array.item: Fear of light and excessive tearing
Eyes have swollen or draining pus
Eyes are red or have a discharge
No signs to classify for congenital or eye infection

string-array.name: young_array_feeding_problem
string-array.item: Breastfeeds less than 8 times in 24 hours
Not low weight for age and no other signs of inadequate feeding

string-array.name: young_array_special_treatments
string-array.item: Baby less than a day old and membranes are raptured
Mother confirmed Hiv positive and not on ARVs
Mother has noy been counslled on infant treatment
Mother started TB treatment months before delivery

resources.string:
• Give Artemeter + Lumefantrine (AL).
 • Give one dose of paracetamol in clinic for high fever (>38.5 degrees).
 • Give Vitamin A.
 • Follow up in 2 days if fever persists.
 • Advise when to return immediately .
 • If fever is present every day > 7 days assess or refer.

•Give first dose of Chloramphenicol 
 •Treat for and to prevent low blood sugar 
 •Keep the child warm
 •Treat wheeze if present 
 •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital"

• Give Cotrimoxazole for 5 days 
 •Give Vitamin A. 
 •Treat wheeze if present 
 •Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy
 •If coughing for 14 days or more,Screen for TB or refer
 •Check for Hiv infection 
 •Advise mother when to return immediately
 •Follow-up in 2 days

• If coughing for 14 days or more screen for TB or refer
 •Treat wheeze of present
 •Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy
 •Advise mother when to return immediately.
 •Follow-up in 5 days if not improving.

•Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.Advise the mother to continue breatsfeeding.
 •Give fluid for severe dehdration
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Zinc Sulphate 
 •If there is no other severe classification
 •If child is 2yrs or older and there is cholera in your area give Erythromycin

• If the child has a severe classification 
 •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.Advise the mother to continue breatsfeeding.
 •Give fluid and food for some dehydration 
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Zinc Sulphate 
 •Follow-up in 2days if not improving

• If the child has a severe classification 
 •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.Advise the mother to continue breatsfeeding.
 •Give fluid and food for some dehydration 
 •Give vitamin A
 •Give Zinc Sulphate
 •Follow-up in 5 days if not improving

•Treat dehydration before referral unless the child has another severe classification 
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Zinc Sulphate
 •Give Multivitamin / Mineral supllements 
 •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way

• Advise the mother on feeding a child who has PERSISTENT DIARRHOEA
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Zinc Sulphate 
 •Give Multivitamin supplements 
 •Check for HIV infection 
 •Follow up in 5 days

• Immediately resuscitate using a bag and mask if the baby:
 	-Is not breathing at all even when stimulated or
 	-Is gasping or
 	 Has a respiratory rate less 20 breaths per minute.
 • If convulsing now, give anticonvulsants.
 • Give first dose of Benzylpenicillin and Gentamicin.
 • Treat to prevent low blood sugar.
 • Advise mother how to keep the infant warm an the way to the hospital.
 • Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.

• Give Cotrimoxazole.
 • Teach the mother to treat local infections at home.
 • Advise mother to give home care for young infant.
 • Follow-up in two days.
• Advise mother to give home care to the young infant.

• Re-warm young infant and reassess after 1 hour.Read on kangaroo warming.
 • Treat to prevent low blood sugar.
 • Advise mother to give home care to the young infant.
 • Advise mother when to return immediately.
• Treat to prevent low blood sugar.\n • Advise mother how to keep the baby warm on the way to the hospital.\n • Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.

• Advise caregiver to expose the baby to the direct sunlight for at least an hour a day.
 • Advise mother when to return immediately.
 • Advise mother to give home care to the infant.
 • Follow up in 2 days.
• Advise mother to give home care to the infant.
• Admit or refer immediately to the hospital or appropriate unit within the facility.
• Admit or refer immediately to the hospital or appropriate unit within the facility.
• Admit or refer immediately to the hospital or appropriate unit within the facility.

• Give fisrt dose of Benzylpenicillin and Gentamicin.
 • Apply first dose of Tetracycline.
 • Treat to prevent low blood sugar.
 • Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.
 • Advise mother on how to keep the baby warm on the way to the hospital.
• Teach mother how to treat eye infection at home.\n • Advise the mother to give home care.\n • Follow up in 2 days.
• Advise the mother to give home care for the child.

• Admit or refer URGENTLY TO HOSPITAL with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.Advise mother to continue breatfeeding.
 • Advice mother to keep the young infant warm on the way to hospital or...
 • If infant does not have VERY SEVERE DISEASE: Give fluid for severe dehydration.
 • Give Zinc Sulphate.

• Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital with mother giving frequent sips of ORS on the way.
 • Advise mother to continue breastfeeding.
 • Give fluid and food for some dehydration.
 • Give zinc sulphate.

• Give fluids to treat diarrhoea at home.
 • Give zinc sulphate.
 • Advise mother when to return immediately.
 • Follow up in 5 days if not improving.
• If the young infant is dehydrated, treat dehydration before referral unless the infant has also a VERY SEVERE DISEASE.\n • Admit or refer to hospital.

• Give first dose of Benzylpenicillin and Gentamicin.
 • Treat the child for or prevent low blood sugar.
 • Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.
 • Advise mother how to keep the infant warm on the way.

• Treat, counsel and follow up existing infections.
 • Initiate or continue with Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis.
 • Give vitamin A.
 • Assess child's feeding and provide appropriate counselling to mother.
 • For children with positive TB contact, screen for TB and manage accordingly or refer to appropriate unit.
 • Follow up after one month.
 • Offer comprehensive management of HIV or refer to appropriate unit.

• Treat, counsel and follow up existing infections.
 • Initiate or continue with Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis.
 • Give and continue with Nevirapine prophylaxisas per the national PMTCT guidelines.
 • Give vitamin A.
 • Assess child's feeding and provide appropriate counselling to mother.

• Treat, counsel and follow up existing infections.
 • Initiate or continue with Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis.
 • Give vitamin A.
 • Assess child's feeding and provide appropriate counselling to mother.
 • Test to confirm HIV infection.
 • Follow up after one month.
 • Offer comprehensive management of HIV or refer to appropriate unit.
• Manage presenting conditions according to IMCI and other recommended National guidelines.\n • Advise the mother about feeding and about her own health.

• Advise the mother to breastfeed as often and for as long as the infant wants,day and night.
 • If not well attached or suckling effectively,teach and show correct positioning and attachment.
 • If breastfeeding less than 8 times in 24 hours,advise to increase frequency of feeding.
 • If receiving other foods or drinks,counsel mother about breastfeeding more, reducing other foods or drinks, and using a cup.
 • If not breastfeeding at all:
 	- Refer for breastfeeding counselling and possible relactation.
 • Advise about correctly preparing breast milk substitutes and using a cup.
 • If a HIV positive mother has chosen not to breastfeed, give feeding advice. Give Vitamin A.
 • If thrush or mouth ulcers, tach the mother to treat thrush and mouth ulcers at home.
 • Check for HIV infection.
 • Advise mother to give home care for the young infant.
 • Follow any feeding problem,thrush or mouth ulcers in 2 days.
 • Follow up low weight for age in 14 days.
• Advise mother to give home care for the young infant. \n • Praise the mother for feeding the infant well.

• Treat to prevent low blood sugar. 
 • Keep baby warm.
 • Advise mother to keep the baby warm.
 • Admit or refer urgently to hospital.
• Manage as for FEEDING PROBLEM OR LOW WEIGHT. \n • Advice mother to keep the young infant warm.\n • Followup in 14 days.
• Advise mother to give home care to the young infant.

• Give babay 1st dose of Benzylpenicillin and Gentamicin.
 • Treatment to prevent low blood sugar.
 • Keep warm.
 • Admit or refer urgently to hospital.
• Give baby single dose of bentathine penicilin.\n • Ensure mother and partner are treated. • Follow up in 14days.

• Give ARV prophylaxis to the newborn.
 • Counsel on infant feeding options.
 • Give special counselling to breast feeding omther.Emphasize on exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months.
 • Teach the mother replacement feeding if that's her choice and meets AFASS criteria.
 • Inform mother of DNA PCR test at 6 weeks.
 • Follow up in 14 days.
• Give infant Isoniazid prophylaxis for 6 months.\n • Give BCG vaccination to the infant only when baby\'s treatment is completed.\n • Follow up in 14 days.

•Treat with Ciproflaxacin 
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Zinc Sulphate 
 •Follow-up in 2 Days

•Give first dose of Artesunate for severe malaria 
 •Give first dose of Chloramphenicol 
 •Treat the child to prevent low blood sugar
 •Give one dose of parcetamol in clinic for high fever( >38.5 degrees Celsius)

•Give one dose of parcetamol in clinic for high fever( >38.5 degrees Celsius)
 •Assess for other posible causes of fever 
 •Follow up in two days if fever persists
 •If fever is present every day for more than 7days assess further or refer

•Give vitamin A 
 •Notify, take blood sample for confirmation
 •Advise mother when to return immediately

•Give first dose of Artesunate for severe malaria

•Give Vitamin A 
 •If pus draining from the eye, treat eye infection with tetracycline eye ointment
 •Notify, take blood sample for confirmation, refer or Admit URGENTLY to hospital

•Give Vitamin A 
 •If pus draining from the eye, treat eye infection with tetracycline eye ointment
 •If mouth ulcers,treat with gentian voilet or nystatin
 •Follow-up in two days
 •If child has no indication for referral,notify and draw blood sample for confirmation of measles
•Give vitamin A if not received in th last 1 month\n •If child has no indication for referral,draw blood and send for confirmation
•Give first dose of Chloramphenicol \n •Give first dose of paracetamol for pain\n •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.

•Give Cotrimoxazole for 5 days 
 •Give paracetamol for pain
 •Dry the ear by wicking 
 •Check for HIV infection
 •Follow-up in 5 days
•Dry the ear by wicking \n •Follow-up in 5 days \n •Check for HIV infection
• No additional treatment\n

•Give Vitamin A 
 •Treat for and to prevent low blood sugar
 •Keep the child warm
 •Admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital

•Assess the child's feeding and counsel the mother on feeding 
 •If growth is faltering for 2 consecutive months,assess further or refer to the hospital 
 •Give Iron and Folate 
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Give Artemeter + Lumefantrine (AL) if high malaria risk
 •Give mebendazole or albendazole if the child is 1 year or older and has not had a dose in the last 6 months 
 •If T.B. contact positive assess further or refer.

 •Advise mother when to come immediately
 •Follow up in 5 days

•Treat, counsel and follow up existing infection
 •Initiate or continue with Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Assess child's feeding and provide appropriate counseling to mother 
 •For children with positive TB contact,screen for TB and manage accordingly or refer to appropriate unit
 •Follow up after one month.
 •Offer comprehensive management ofHIV or refer to appropriate unit

•Treat, counsel and follow up existing infection
 •Initiate or continue with Cotrimoxazole prophylaxis
 •Give and continue with Nevirapine prophylaxis as per the national PMTCT guidelines 
 •Give vitamin A 
 •Assess child's feeding and provide appropriate counselling to mother 
 •Offer routine follow up for growth and development, nutrition, immunization
 •Follow up after one month 
 •Repeat HIV antibody test at 9 Months, if negative, repeat test again at 18 months and continue with normal under fives clinic
 •If antibody test at 9 months is positive, collect DBS sample for confirmatory DNA PCR test.

After 2 days 
 Check the child for general danger signs.
 Assess the child for diarrhoea.
 Ask:
 	-Is the child breathing slower.
 	-Is there less fever?
 	-Is the child eating better?

• If chest indrawing or a danger sign give intramuscular antibiotic. Then admit or refer urgently to Hospital.\n •If breathing rate,fever and eating have not improved, change to secondline antibiotic and advise the mother to return in 2 days or refer.(If this child had measles within the last 3 months or is known or suspected to have symptomatic HIV infections,refer.) \n •If breathing slower, less fever, or eating better, complete the 5 days of antibiotic.

After 2 days
 Assess the child for diarrhoea.
 Ask:
 	-Are there fewer stools.
 	-Is there less blood in the stool?
 	-Is there less fever?
 	-Is there less abdominal pain?
 	-Is the child eating better?

•If the child is dehydrated, treat dehyration according to classification.
 •If number of stools, fever, abdominnal pain, or eating is worse:Admit or refer to hospital.
 •If the condition is the same: add metronidazole to the treatment.
 	 Give it for 5 days. Advise the mother to continue ciproflaxin and zinc and to return in 2 days. Exceptions if the child
 	 1. Is less than 12 months old 
	 2. Was dehydrated on the first visit 
	 3. Had measles within the last 3 months 
 For the three Admit or refer urgently to hospital. 
 
 • If fewer stools, less blood in the stools, less fever, less abdominal pain, and eating better, continue giving ciproflaxin and zinc until finished.

After 5 days
 Ask: 
 -Has the Diarrhoea stopped.
 -how many loose stools is the child having per day?

• If the diarrhoea has not stopped(child is still having 3 or more loose stools per day), do a full reassessment of the child.Give any treatment needed. Then refer to hospital.
 • If the diarrhoea has stopped(child having less than 3 loose stools per day). Tel the mother to follow th usual feeding recommendations for the child's age, but give one extra meal every day 1 month. Ask her to continue giving zinc foe total of 10 days.

 • NB: Attention to diet is an essential part of the management of a child with persistent diarrhoea.

After 2 days 
 Check the child for general danger signs or chest indrawing
 Assess the child for cough or difficult breathing.

 Ask: 
 	-Is the child breathing slower?
 	-Is the child stillwheezing.
 	-Is the child eating better.

Child under 1 year 

 • If chest indrawing or a danger sign give intramuscular antibiotic.Then admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital .
 • If breathing slower,no wheezing and eating better continue the treatment for 5 days.

 Child 1 year and over 

 • If chest indrawing or a danger sign give intramuscular antibiotic. Then admit or refer urgently to Hospital.
 • If breathing rate and eating have not improved, change to second line antibiotic, and if still wheezing continue oral bronchodilator. Advise the mother to return in 2 days.
 • If breathing slower,no wheezing and eating better,continue the treatment for 5 days.

If fever persists after 2 days, or recurs within 14 days:
 Do a full reassessment of the child.
 Assess for other causes of fever

• If the child has any general danger sign or stiff neck, treat as VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE.
 • If the child has any cause of fever other than malaria, provide treatment.
 • If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever:Give Oral DIHYDROARTEMISININ-PIPERAQUINE(DHA-PPQ).Give paracetamol.If child is ubder 5 kg and was given DHA-PPQ assess further.
 • Advice mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists 
		 - if the fever has been present every day 7 days,refer for assessment.

After 5 days: 
 Do a full reassessment of the child.
 Assess for other causes of fever.

• If the child has any general danger sign or stiff neck, treat as VERY SEVERE FEBRILE DISEASE.
 • If the child has any cause of fever other then malaria, provide treatment. • If malaria is the only apparent cause of fever:
 		 Treat with the first-line antimalarial.Give paracetamol.Advise the mother to return again in 2 days if the fever persists.
 		 If fever has been present every day for 7 days, referfor assessment.

After 5 days: 
 • Reassess for ear problem.
 • Measure the child's temperature.

• If there is tender swelling behind the ear or high fever, admit or refer URGENTLY to hospital.
 • Acute ear infection:if ear pain continues or discharge persists,treat with 5 more days of the same antibiotic. Conitnue wicking to dry the ear.Follow up in 5 days.
 • Chronic ear infection:Check that the mother is wicking the ear correctly.Encourage her to continue. Review in 2 weeks.
 If ear discharge continues for more than 2 months:Admit or refer to hospital.
 • If no ear pain or discharge, praise the mother for her careful treatment.If she has not yet finished the 5 days of antibiotic, tell her to use it till treatmentis completed.

After 2 days: 
 • Look for red eyes and pus draining from the eyes.
 • Look at mouth ulcers.
 • Smell the mouth.

• If pus is draining from the eye, ask the mother to describe how she has treated the eye infection.
 		-If treatment has been correct, admit or refer to hospital.
 		-If treatment has not been correct, teach mother correct treatment.
 • If the pus is gone but redness remains,continue the treatment.
 • If no pus or redness,stop the treatment.
After 5 days: \n Reassess feeding: See questions according to counsel the mother tips.

• Counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problems. If you counsel the mother to make significant changes in feeding, ask her to bring the child back after 5 Days.\n • If the child is very low weight for age, ask the mother to return 14 days after the initial visit to measure the child\'s weight gain.

After 14 days: 
 • Give iron and folate.Advise mother to return in 14 days formore Iron and Folate.
 • Continue giving Iron and Folate every 14 days for 2 months.
 • If the child has palmar pallor after 2 months, refer for assessment
After 14 days: \n Weigh the child and determine if the child is still very low weight for age. reassess feeding\n

• If the child is no longer very low weight for age, praise the mother and encourage her to continue with the feeding until catch up growth is realized.\n • If child is still very low weight for age but gaining weight,encourage the mother to continue with feeding. Counsel the mother about any feeding problem found. Ask the mother to return again in 14 days.\n Continue to see the child every one month until the child is normal weight for age. • Admit or refer if the child has lost weight. You do not think that feeding will improve or the child continues to lose weight.

HIV INFECTED CHILD 
 After one month: 
 • Assess the child\s general condition. Do a full reassessment.
 • Treat the child for any condition found.
 • Ask for any feeding problems, counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problems.
 • Advise mother to bring the child back If any new illness develops or she is worried.
 • Counsel the mother or any other problems and rescue community support is being given .Refer for further counselling if necessary.
 • Continue with routine follow up for growth and development, nutrition, immunization, vitamin A, deworming.
 • Assess adherence to ART and Cotrimoxazole and advice accordingly.

HIV INFECTED CHILD TESTED NEGATIVE FOR DNA PCR 
 • Assess the child's general condition. DO a full reassessment.
 • Ask for any feeding problems or poor appetite,counsel the mother or continue feeding problems.
 • Treat the child for any condition found.
 • Start or continue with nevirapine prophylaxis.
 • Continue with routine follow up for growth and development,nutrition, immunization, vitamin A, deworming.
 • Follow up schedule of HIV Exposed infant: 6weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 6 months, 9months, 12 months, 15months, 18months.
 • Refer to early infant Diagnosis (EID) algorithm for confirmation of HIV status.
 • Refer to the HIV exposed infant follow up card and register for further follow up instructions.

After 2 Days: 
 Look at the umbilicus.Is it red or draining pus?
 Does redness extend to the skin?
 Look at the skin pustules. Are there many or severe pustsles?
 Look at the eyes.Is there pus? Is there associated swelling or redness of the eyelids?

• If pus or redness remains or is worse, admit or refer to hospital.
 • If pus and redness are improved, tell the mother to continue giving the 5 days of antibiotic and continue treating the local infection at home. 

 • If the pustules are same or worse, admit or refer to hospital.
 • If skin pustules are improved, tell the mother to continue treating the local infection at home.

After 2 Days: 
 -Are palms and soles yellow?.

\t\t • If palms and soles are yellow or age 14 days or more, admit or refer to hospital.\n \t\t • If palms and soles are not yellow and age is less than 14 days, advise on home care and when to return immediately.

After 2 Days: 
 Look for pus from the eyes.

• If pus draining from the eyes, ask the mother to describe how she has treated the eye infection. 
 			 - If treatment has been correct, admit or refer ro hospital.
 			 - If treatment has not been correct, teach the mother correct treatment and advise her to give treatment for 5 days. 
Follow up in 2 days. 
		 • If no pus,ask th mother to continue treatment for 5 days.
After 2 Days:\n Ask - Has the diarrhoea stopped ?.\n

\t\t • If the diarrhoea has not stopped.Assess and treat the young infant for diarrhoea.\n \t\t • If the diarrhoea has stopped, tell the mother to continue exclusive breastfeeding . Advise her to continue giving zinc to complete 10 days.

After 2 days :
 Reassess feeding.
 Ask about any feeding problem found on the initial visit

• Counsel the mother about any new or continuing feeding problem. If you counsel the mother to make significant changes in feeding. ask her to bring the young infant back after 2 days.
 		 • If the young infant is low weight for age, ask the mother to return 14 days after the visit to measure the young infant's weight gain. 
 		 Exception: 
 	If you do not think that feeding will improve, or if the young infant has not lost weight, admit or refer the child.
After 2 days\n Weigh the young infant and determine if the infant is still low weight for age.\n

Reassess feeding.
 		 • Counsel the mother about any new or continuing problems. If you counsel the mother to make significant changes in feeding,ask her to bring the young infant back after 2 days
 		 • If the young infant is low weight for age,ask the mother to return 14 days after the initial visit to measure the young infant's weight gain. 

 Exception: 
 If you do not think that feeding will improve, or if the young infant has lost weight, admit or refer the child.
After 2 days\n Look for ulcers or patches in the mouth ulcers(thrush).\n

Reassess feeding.
 		 •If thrush or mouth ulcers are worse or the infant has problems with attachmentor sucking.admit or refer to hospital. 
 		 •If thrush or mouth ulcers are the same or better, and the baby is feeding well continue with Gentian or Nystatin for a total of 5 days.

ASK
 Has the infant had convulsions?
 ASK and LOOK:
 Is the infant not able to feed or breast feed?
 LOOK, LISTEN, FEEL 

 • Look for breathing: Is the baby gasping or not breathing at all even when stimulated.
 • Count the breaths in one minute. Repeat the count if elevated.
 • Look for severe chest indrawing .
 • Look and listen for grunting or wheezing.
 • Look for nasal flaring.
 • Look for central cyanosis.
 • Look and feel for bulging fontanel.
 • Look for pus draining from the ear.
 • Look at the umbilicus. Is it red or draining pus?
 • Measure temperature or feel for low or high body temperature.
 • Look for skin pustules.
 • See if the young infant is drowsy (Lethargic) or unconscious.
 • Look at the young infant’s movements. Does the infant not move even when stimulated?
 • Listen for very high pitched cry.
 • Look for stiff neck.

IF YES, ASK:
 For how long?
 LOOK AND FEEL:n • Crossed eyes
 • Excessive tearing.
 • Fear of light.
 • Clouding of the cornea.
 • Squeezing of the eyes.
 • Red eyes.
 • Whiteness in the pupil.
 • Eyes discharge, if yes for how long?
 • Eyes draining pus.
 • Swollen eyes.

CHECK FOR EYE INFECTIONS
 IF YES, ASK: 
 For how long?
 LOOK AND FEEL:
 • Crossed eyes
 • Excessive tearing
 • Fear of light
 • Clouding of the cornea
 • Squeezing of the eyes
 • Red eyes
 • Whiteness in the pupil
 • Eyes discharge, if yes for how long?
 • Eyes draining pus
 • Swollen eyes
